title: Dan Birdwell
text:
Dan Birdwell was an American college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player. A <a href="defensive%20lineman">defensive lineman</a>, he played collegiately for the <a href="University%20of%20Houston">University of Houston</a> and professionally for the <a href="Oakland%20Raiders">Oakland Raiders</a> of the <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> from 1962 to 1969. He was the starting left defensive tackle with <a href="Tom%20Keating%20%28American%20football%29">Tom Keating (American football)</a> on the right side for the <a href="1967%20AFL%20season">1967</a> AFL Champion Raiders with their 13-1 win-loss record and on the losing side in the <a href="Super%20Bowl%20II">second AFL-NFL World Championship game</a>. In that season, the front four of Birdwell, Keating, <a href="Ike%20Lassiter">Ike Lassiter</a>, and <a href="Ben%20Davidson">Ben Davidson</a> combined for impressive totals of 67 sacks and 666 yards lost.
Birdwell is credited with the following quote regarding the necessary mindset to play professional football: "You have to play this game like somebody just hit your mother with a two by four."
Birdwell died of a massive heart attack at age 37 on February 14, 1978.
